##Dialogue Ning Yi: Wuhan should be lifted by the end of April at the latest, otherwise it is easy to cause many secondary disasters

Wechat Dingxiangwang

Function introduction, thousands of medical workers on-line home. We know the pain and pleasure of medicine. In Clove Garden, you can keep abreast of the latest information, read in-depth reports and communicate with your peers.

In recent days, China's epidemic has levelled off and parts of the country have begun to clear. At the same time, ports around the country are under pressure as large numbers of people cross the border from abroad on their return journey.

As the international epidemic enters the second half, how should China deal with the importation of cases from abroad? Will this affect China's current achievements in fighting the epidemic? How long will this outbreak last? Given the evidence so far, is it likely that rising temperatures will help contain the outbreak? WHEN WILL WUHAN BE LIFTED? Will going back to work for masks become the norm? ..

Here is a conversation between Clove Garden and Ning Yi, professor and Executive Director of the Institute of Public Health, Peking University.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Clove Garden: On March 11, the World Health Organization Organization declared the COVID-19 a global pandemic, and as early as late February, several international epidemiologists said the epidemic had met the criteria for a global pandemic. Do you think the WHO announcement is too late? Would it be better to alert countries to the outbreak if it were announced earlier?

Ning Yi: In fact, before the World Health Organization Organization announced the global pandemic, it had already been quite active. While the term Pandemic is not used, there have been repeated warnings not to lose sight of the potentially devastating impact of the outbreak.

As for the question of whether an earlier announcement would better alert countries to the outbreak, I think in some ways World Health Organization is just a technical multilateral organization, there is not enough power to bind countries to take strong measures to contain the epidemic. Until then, the world should communicate and coordinate its efforts better.

Clove Garden: UK Chief Scientific Adviser Patrick Vallance said: "consider the long-term goal of getting enough Britons infected, that is, immunising the population. ". What do you think of the mass immunization strategy in the UK?

Ning Yi: in the face of an epidemic, countries around the world have three strategies to choose from: the first, like our country, aims to eliminate the virus and stop it; the second, tries to delay the development of the epidemic and wait for the emergence of a vaccine or a specific drug; the third, we believe the heat will keep the virus at bay, and we're counting on the rising temperatures.

The current cases in the UK are more sporadic, more mobilised, more resource-intensive, and not necessarily supported by the public. The first strategy will be more difficult to implement, while the third strategy is too unstable, so only the second strategy can be adopted. By "herd immunity, " I mean the worst outcome of the second strategy: There has been no specific drug or vaccine, and the only way to get through it is to infect the majority of the population.

In the UK, where there are more than six thousand, six hundred people, 60% of the population, or nearly forty million people, would need to be infected to become immunised. Of those forty million, there are many who have underlying diseases or are elderly, and they have a high case fatality rate, so they are not well protected until they reach 60% of the natural population.

But what we found was that after scientists had told us this worst case scenario, the British people spontaneously started closing schools, canceling meetings, quarantining, and taking precautions. Therefore, this may also be the British government mobilizes the public to fight the epidemic enthusiasm of a "tactic. ".

DXY: What do you think of the current outbreak control in Japan?

Ning Yi: Judging from the rising curve of the number of confirmed cases in Japan, it can be said that the development of the epidemic situation has been delayed quite successfully. I think this is due to the following: 1. The people of the country have good hygienic habits. The country as a whole has experience of various disasters and is able to cope with them better. 3. There are rich per capita medical resources and a well-functioning classification system; 4. The government can manage people's panic better. Citizens can voluntarily opt for home quarantine after a diagnosis. There's a lot we can learn from this.

But Japan's case fatality rate is not low, at 3.3% , suggesting that many potential patients are not being tested. We can wait another two weeks, to see if Japan can control the disease, while slowing it down, and the data show that the epidemic is likely to pick up in the future.

In addition, I personally believe that even if the epidemic in Japan can be brought under control in the summer, it will be difficult for the Olympic Games to be held as planned because the Japanese government can not provide strong evidence under the current policy, this suggests that the risk of infection is low enough for both competitors and spectators, and that the national epidemic is likely to be poorly controlled.

Clove Garden: The epidemic situation in China has tended to ease, some areas began to clear, at the same time, the international epidemic has just entered the second half, there is still a growing trend, this will affect China's current achievements in fighting the epidemic?

Ning Yi: We have a lot of experience in preventing imported cases, such as Zaire Ebolavirus and H7N9 avian influenza, and we are doing very well. This time, it's GonNa cost you, but it's GonNa hold. Even if a small number of imported cases trigger an epidemic, I believe it can be contained to a very small extent, but the entry point to become the forefront of epidemic prevention, is a very critical new campaign.

For now, the need for the entire international community to develop a unified control strategy for the epidemic is very important. Some countries aim to eliminate the virus, while others hope to survive the crisis through mass immunization, which may put enormous pressure on the former's ports of entry.

Countries need to reach a consensus on the technical level: Is it best to eliminate the virus or to keep it at a low level of prevalence?

But China's current experience suggests that strong isolation and treatment can contain an outbreak, while other countries may find it more difficult. Of course, such a unification would be difficult to achieve and would require concerted efforts by the World Health Organization Organization and several major powers.

Clove Garden: Recently, a large number of Chinese and overseas Chinese have set off on their return journey. The pressure on the entry ports in Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, Guangzhou and other places has suddenly increased. At present, Beijing has requested that the entry personnel be uniformly tested for the new coronavirus, do you think it is necessary for other regions to take this measure?

Ning Yi: As far as I know, most of the cities have in fact been carrying out unified examination of the entry personnel. With the decline of cases in our country and the surge of cases abroad, the threat to us from imported cases is already as great as the impact that Wuhan had on other cities, therefore, the strategic goal of China's anti-epidemic has gradually shifted from "fighting the war of annihilation around Wuhan" to "focusing on the management of entry ports to prevent imported cases" .

Our country's current goal is to maintain zero cases, and it has been largely successful, but there are still many factors that we can not determine that will affect our results.

Therefore, I think the immigration management strategy depends on the following three points: 1. Changes in the international epidemic situation, which we need to assess over time; 2. Can Our ports of entry manage 100 percent of such a large number of returnees? We have not yet used the military medical personnel to assist. Will the small number of cases coming into the country form an outbreak? If there is no outbreak or controlled decay, then the current strategy can continue.

Of course, the pressure on customs and some hospitals will be very great, but our investment in customs and hospitals is still very small compared to the cost that the whole country may have to pay. It's worth it if you want to keep what you've worked for. We need to support the customs and the hospitals, just as we did in Wuhan.

Clove Garden: At present, many districts have started to resume work. Recently, Shanghai Yangpu District issued a notice stating that "all commercial enterprises will cancel the original requirement for consumers to take temperature measurements, scan codes and wear masks when entering stores. All QR codes previously posted will be removed, all the doors and passageways of the shopping malls are open and no restrictions are imposed. Do you think it will be a normal practice to return to work in the near future?

Ning Yi: First of all, I believe that as long as there are no new cases for more than 14 days, it is possible to resume work in all areas. In particular, the new cases in some areas are not new, but come from suspected cases. Building epidemic prevention capabilities that can detect possible transmission in a timely manner is less costly than stopping the whole country or city, and can further strengthen the construction of health and epidemic prevention teams from actual combat.

At present, our public awareness of the disease has been strengthened, local governments through travel management to form a firewall, even if a small epidemic in some areas, we can rely on rich experience to respond in a timely manner.

As for whether to wear a mask after returning to work, I think it would be better to ask those who feel unwell to wear a mask. This would save most people the trouble of wearing a mask. The guidelines for the public to wear masks scientifically, issued by the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention on March 18, also stressed that the general public does not need to wear masks in uncrowded and well-ventilated homes or outdoors, keep a spare mask handy in low-risk, densely populated office areas and use it when in close (1m) contact with others.

Clove Garden: Some scholars have pointed out recently that spraying disinfectant on the sky, roads, vehicles and people is harmful during the anti-epidemic period. Do you agree with this view? After each local enterprise, the market resumes work, how should use the disinfection liquid to carry on the place disinfection correctly?

Ning Yi: I agree with this view. What is the use of spraying disinfectant on the sky or the road? To Kill the Aerosol? But we can only be infected by aerosols if we are exposed to high concentrations of aerosols for a long time in a relatively closed environment. But buses, businesses and shopping malls should be disinfected, but private cars need not be.

LILAC GARDEN: According to your conjecture, how long will this epidemic last? Given the evidence so far, is it likely that rising temperatures will help contain the outbreak?

Ning Yi: I think rising temperatures may help contain the epidemic, for three reasons: 1. Current data suggest that countries near the equator are less affected; 2. It was in the summer that SARS suddenly disappeared 17 years ago. From the point of view of aetiology, the virulence of the virus will be weakened under high temperature. If this hypothesis holds true, the global epidemic could change dramatically by the summer. However, the virus may still be circulating in cold regions near the Poles or in the southern hemisphere, and could cause a new global outbreak in the fall and winter, so we still need specific drugs and vaccines.

But I think the most important thing is to strike while the iron is hot and solve the domestic problems as soon as possible. I think by the middle or end of April at the latest, Wuhan should be lifted, and the rest of the country should be restored to the order before the outbreak, otherwise it will be easy to trigger many secondary disasters, for example, people in Wuhan are prone to psychological diseases, cardiovascular diseases, tumor diseases and so on.

But before we can do that, we need to develop a mechanism that can respond quickly when an outbreak is likely to reignite. As things stand, the cost of establishing such a mechanism is far less than the cost of maintaining the current state. The cost of the latter is calculated by the day, a day late recovery, will cause huge losses.

Clove Garden: On March 16, clinical trials of the recombinant new crown vaccine developed by academician Chen Wei were launched. On the same day, the Institute of Medical Science announced the first phase of clinical trials of a new coronavirus vaccine. If the trial is successful, how long will it take for these vaccines to be widely available? Could this be a new watershed in international outbreak control?

Ning Yi: Most Vaccines Require Phase III clinical trials. Academician Chen Wei's team got the first injection, indicating that the first phase of the trial has already started. A lot of our news now says "successful Development" directly in the title, which is a problem, because it is still far from being able to apply on a large scale. The process typically takes more than 18 months, and even a miracle can take at least half a year.

I can understand that the masses of the people now because of the love of life, are very eager to vaccine or specific drugs on the market, but the vaccine, drug development on the market this process is often very cruel. When you invest a lot of manpower, material resources, financial resources, often find that the final results let you down: May Be less than expected, may also be due to excessive side effects. So when it comes to vaccines, you have to be very careful about what you say.

You said "watershed. " I love that word. If a vaccine does come on the market, it will be a real watershed moment, and it will help us turn passivity into activism. We can not repeat the tragedy of the 1918 flu pandemic, in which there was no vaccine and tens of millions of people died.

Clove Garden: There has been a lot of debate about the identity of patient zero. At this stage, do we still need to go back to patient zero?

Ning Yi: Personally, I think it is important to trace back to patient zero. We need to know through which wild animals, in what way the disease is transmitted to our people. We now suspect that the virus comes from bats or pangolins, but if it comes from other wild animals, and we don't raise the alarm, we could trigger the next pandemic.

It's just that we can only go back to December 1st at the earliest, and there's very little evidence before that. Now, after all this time, it's GonNa be even harder. All we can do is implement the relevant policies and strictly manage the wild animals.

Illustration Source: Illustration bug idea
